page.title: 01PAINSCASTLE - HISTORY
page.content: Painscastle is a typical Welsh border village. Historically it was so positioned for two reasons. Firstly it was the head of the Lower Elfael commote till the Norman Conquest. In 1231 the castle, of Norman origin, was constructed at the request of King Henry III for the Fitzpayn family to strengthen and control the border. The village has an interesting peculiarity in that its farms are nucleared so that lands radiate from farmhouses built under the castle 'shelter'. In the 17th century Painscasle found importance as a place on the drovers routes - the cattle being driven from mid Wales, across the Wye at Erwood, through Painscastle en route to London. Until this century the Petty Sessions for the area were held in the village and it is still the centre for the Rural District council.
